holdings.text: the whole process, including the order made under s. 12 of the Act, is a quasi-judicial one and not administrative as contended for by the defendants-respondents.

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, hold that the whole process, including the order made under s. 12 of the Act, is a quasi-judicial one and not administrative as contended for by the defendants-respondents.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedure under ss.11-12 requires enquiry, lis between Watandar and alienee, hearing parties, evidence, reasons in writing; order appealable under ss.77,79; discretion exercised judicially; distinguishes English cases like Robinson.

holdings.text: the Governments order of October, 1946, must be deemed to be a judicial or a quasi-judicial order.

anchor.surface_text: When an authority exercises its revisional powers it necessarily acts in a judicial or quasi-judicial capacity. Therefore, the Governments order of October, 1946, must be deemed to be a judicial or a quasi-judicial order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Government exercised revisional jurisdiction under s.79 after thorough enquiry by revenue officials in presence of parties, opportunity to adduce evidence; akin to s.12 order.

holdings.text: Finality attaches to the Governments order under s. 79 and in the absence of any express provision empowering it to review the order we are clear that the subsequent order made by the Government on May 2, 1947 is ultra vires and beyond its jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: Such an order cannot be set aside or revised or modified just as an administrative order can be under s. 74. Finality attaches to the Governments order under s. 79 and in the absence of any express provision empowering it to review the order we are clear that the subsequent order made by the Government on May 2, 1947 is ultra vires and beyond its jurisdiction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Quasi-judicial orders under s.79 attract finality; no review power without statutory provision; unlike administrative orders under s.74.

holdings.text: Section 74 is thus clearly a provision which relates to orders made by the Collector without making any investigation in writing.

anchor.surface_text: These provisions do not represent the totality of the Collectors power under the Act. Section 74 is thus clearly a provision which relates to orders made by the Collector without making any investigation in writing. This provision, therefore, does not assist the defendants.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.74 general control over Collector applies to administrative duties without written investigation; ss.11 requires reasons implying investigation; appeal under s.77 only for investigated decisions.

holdings.text: considering all these prayers together we are of opinion that no relief was in fact sought against the Government and it was made only a formal party to the suit. If that view is correct the provisions of s. 4(a) of the Bombay Revenue Jurisdiction Act, 1876 will not stand in the way.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, considering all these prayers together we are of opinion that no relief was in fact sought against the Government and it was made only a formal party to the suit. If that view is correct the provisions of s. 4(a) of the Bombay Revenue Jurisdiction Act, 1876 will not stand in the way.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prayer 1 redundant as orders null ab initio; no possession/obstruction by Government; accounts against defendants 2-4 only; cites precedent that civil courts can examine ultra vires acts/jurisdiction excess; distinguishes Bhujangrao.

precedents.citation: Gullapalli Nageswara Rao v. Andhra Pradesh Road Transport Corporation 1

anchor.surface_text: This Court has held in Gullapalli Nageswara Rao v. Andhra Pradesh Road Transport Corporation 1 , as well as recently in Board of High School and Intermediate Education U.P. v. Ghanshyam Das Gupta 2 , that an order will be deemed to be of quasi-judicial character

precedents.case_name: Gullapalli Nageswara Rao v. Andhra Pradesh Road Transport Corporation
precedents.cited_proposition: an order will be deemed to be of quasi-judicial character not only when there is a contest between one individual and another but also when the contest is between an authority purporting to do an act and a person opposing it provided the statute imposes a duty on the authority to act judicially

precedents.citation: Board of High School and Intermediate Education U.P. v. Ghanshyam Das Gupta 2

Ghanshyam Das Gupta 2 , that an order will be deemed to be of quasi-judicial character not only when there is a contest between one individual and another but also when the contest is between an authority purporting to do an act and a person opposing it provided the statute imposes a duty on the authority to act judicially.

precedents.citation: Ramrao Jankiram Kadam v. The State of Bombay 1

anchor.surface_text: This Court, while dealing with an objection that the suit was barred by the provisions of s. 4 c of the Bombay Revenue Jurisdiction Act has observed recently in Ramrao Jankiram Kadam v. The State of Bombay 1 , as follows

precedents.case_name: Ramrao Jankiram Kadam v. The State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: s.4(c) bars only suits to set aside irregular sales where title passed, not purported sales that are null and void
precedents.cited_holding: Where however there is only a purported sale which does not pass title and the suit is for recovery of possession of property ignoring such a sale, the provision and the bar that it creates have no application.

anchor.surface_text: We may, however, refer to a decision of this Court in Bhujangtao Daulatrao v. Malojirao Daulatrao 1 , which is claimed to support the contention of the defendants.

precedents.citation: The Province of Bombay v. Hormusji 2

anchor.surface_text: The decision in The Province of Bombay v. Hormusji 2 was cited before this Court in support of the contention that civil courts have jurisdiction to decide whether the Government acted in excess of its powers.

precedents.cited_proposition: civil courts can determine if government resolution ultra vires before s.4(b) bar applies

precedents.citation: The Secretary of State v. Musk Co. 2

anchor.surface_text: One such decision is The Secretary of State v. Musk Co. 2 , in which the judicial Committee has observed thus It is settled law that the exclusion of the Civil Courts is not to be readily inferred

precedents.case_name: Secretary of State v. Musk & Co.
precedents.cited_proposition: exclusion of civil courts not readily inferred; civil courts can check compliance with Act or fundamental principles of judicial procedure
precedents.cited_holding: It is settled law that the exclusion of the Civil Courts is not to be readily inferred, but that such exclusion must either be explicitly expressed or clearly implied. It is also well-settled that even if jurisdiction is so excluded, the Civil Courts have jurisdiction to examine into cases where the provisions of the Act have not been complied with, or the statutory tribunal has not acted in conformity with the fundamental principles of judicial procedure.

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, hold that the whole process, including the order made under s. 12 of the Act, is a quasi-judicial one and not administrative as contended for by the defendants-respondents.

edges.explanation: Holding that s.12 order is quasi-judicial addresses issue of whether orders administrative implying suit lies

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we reverse the decision of the High Court which affirmed that of the District Court and restore the decision of the trial court.

When an authority exercises its revisional powers it necessarily acts in a judicial or quasi-judicial capacity. Therefore, the Governments order of October, 1946, must be deemed to be a judicial or a quasi-judicial order.
For these reasons we reverse the decision of the High Court which affirmed that of the District Court and restore the decision of the trial court.

Such an order cannot be set aside or revised or modified just as an administrative order can be under s. 74. Finality attaches to the Governments order under s. 79 and in the absence of any express provision empowering it to review the order we are clear that the subsequent order made by the Government on May 2, 1947 is ultra vires and beyond its jurisdiction.
For these reasons we reverse the decision of the High Court which affirmed that of the District Court and restore the decision of the trial court.

edges.explanation: Holding on s.74 for orders without investigation undercuts quasi-judicial for non-investigative orders, distinguishing pith for ss.11-12

anchor.surface_text: These provisions do not represent the totality of the Collectors power under the Act. Section 74 is thus clearly a provision which relates to orders made by the Collector without making any investigation in writing. This provision, therefore, does not assist the defendants.
For these reasons we reverse the decision of the High Court which affirmed that of the District Court and restore the decision of the trial court.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, considering all these prayers together we are of opinion that no relief was in fact sought against the Government and it was made only a formal party to the suit. If that view is correct the provisions of s. 4(a) of the Bombay Revenue Jurisdiction Act, 1876 will not stand in the way.
For these reasons we reverse the decision of the High Court which affirmed that of the District Court and restore the decision of the trial court.
